did.unittitle: Michigan Woman's Christian Temperance Union records 1874-2006
did.abstract: State chapter of national temperance organization founded in 1874; records include correspondence of early W.C.T.U. workers, Alice E. H. Peters and Ella Eaton Kellogg; also minutes, scrapbooks, and other records of individual Michigan W.C.T.U. districts and chapters.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This record group (donor 5688) was first deposited with the library in 1975. Additional records have been received.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Michigan Woman's Christian Temperance Union records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: With the assistance and encouragement of an Ohio women's temperance union, local Michigan women's temperance groups met in Lansing in February 1874 for the purpose of forming a state organization of their own. Later in 1874 this organization took the name Michigan Woman's Christian Temperance Union (WCTU). The group's main purpose was to work for the outlawing of liquor sales in the state of Michigan. Like other burgeoning state organizations, the Michigan WCTU was organized in part to assist in the formation of local unions which would then mobilize grass-roots support for various prohibition legislation and local option campaigns. In addition, their membership campaigned for woman suffrage and protective legislation for women and children.

The WCTU's greatest influence was in the years leading up to the passage of the eighteenth amendment. With the repeal of this amendment in 1933, the organization lost much of its focus. While continuing to support prohibition legislation, the organization also began to stress education campaigns about related issues, such as drug abuse and drunken driving. By the early 1970s many unions were disbanding because of declining membership and lack of interest; this trend continued through the 1980s and 1990s, although the WCTU continued its work of educating the public about alcohol and drug abuse.

For more detailed histories of the Michigan WCTU, the researcher should consult A Brief History of Michigan Woman's Christian Temperance Union, compiled by Mrs. J.P. Howard and Mrs. Julia R. Parish (1912) and Guide to the Microfilm Edition of Temperance and Prohibition Papers, edited by Randall C. Jimerson, Francis X. Blouin and Charles A. Isetts (1977).

scopecontent.p: The Michigan Woman's Temperance Union records divide into seven series: Correspondence; Miscellaneous and Publicity; Printed Materials; District Records; County Union Records; Local Union Records; and Photographs. The records document the period of the Michigan WCTU's greatest influence, the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, as well as the organization's gradual declining influence following the repeal of the prohibition amendment.

Correspondence (0.5 linear ft.; 1886-1967) contains letters between Michigan WCTU founders and national WCTU leaders, including Frances Willard and Anna Gordon. The series also contains correspondence regarding financial and legal matters dating from the 1960s.

did.unittitle: Letter from Mrs. Jennie Roberts (Deerfield Union) to Anna Gordon 1924

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous and Publicity (0.3 linear ft.; 1915-1974) consists of scrapbooks, song sheets, lecture notes and award certificates, which were produced to promote and publicize the WCTU cause.

did.unittitle: Lecture Series: "The History and Philosophy of the Temperance Movement" undated
Rededication of Children's Temperance Fountain, Belle Isle 1963
Miscellaneous printed material from Ludwig scrapbook
Temperance Song Sheets and Music undated

scopecontent.p: Printed Materials (0.2 linear feet; 1892-2007, most undated) contains pamphlets, brochures, periodicals and hymnals. The series demonstrates the scope and dramatic approach of WCTU literature, much of which takes the form of testimonials.

scopecontent.p: District Records (2.5 linear ft.; 1888-1982) contain minutes of district annual conventions, secretary's books, scrapbooks and treasurer's books. The series includes some records for most of the eighteen WCTU district organizations.

did.unittitle: Fifteenth/ Sixteenth/ Seventeenth Districts Clippings and Constitution 1971-1973

scopecontent.p: County Union Records (3 linear ft.; 1883-1981) contain meeting minutes, secretary's books, membership lists, scrapbooks and treasurer's books. The series documents the day to day activities of WCTU and the coordinating role of county organizations from all over Michigan. The series is arranged alphabetically by county.

did.unittitle: Gratiot County Treasurer's Book and Clippings 1943-1977
Huron-Tuscola County Annual Convention Members List 1960-1976
Banner with slogan "For God, Home and Every Land 1890"
Shiawassee County, Bennington Union Secretary's Books 1935-1959
Shiawassee County, Corunna Union Secretary's Books 1952-1962
Tuscola and Huron Counties Minute Book 1959-1976

scopecontent.p: Local Union Records (9.5 linear ft.; 1874-1991) contain meeting minutes, secretary's books, membership lists, scrapbooks and treasurer's books. The series documents the day to day activities of WCTU at the community level from all over Michigan. Included are substantial records for Grand Rapids and Owosso chapters. The Owosso records contain minutes which date back to 1874, the year of the Michigan WCTU's founding.

did.unittitle: Intercity Council of East Lansing Minutes 1960-1974
Lansing Iota Sigma Chapter Minutes circa 1943-1945

scopecontent.p: Photographs (0.1; ca.1900-1960s) contains portraits of WCTU leaders, including Anna Gordon and Lucy Bliss, as well as group pictures taken at the state conventions of 1908 and 1917.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous: include portrait of Anna Gordon, undated, and group portraits of delegates to state conventions

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The library has separately cataloged published materials of the Michigan Woman's Christian Temperance Union. These include newsletters, annual reports, and minutes and reports of the annual convention. The library also has records from individual local chapters, including Ann Arbor, Battle Creek, Evart, the Flint Federation, Three Oaks, and Ypsilanti.
